intro: Holoschkuhria tetramera, commonly known as the four-parted bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its bell-shaped, blue to purple flowers that bloom in early summer. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features opposite, lanceolate leaves with hairy surfaces. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in alpine meadows and rocky slopes. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
